private_information: You specialize in extracting formal action schemas, predicates, objects, and invariants from natural-language descriptions.
You do not emit PDDL; you produce a clean, solver-ready intermediate specification summarizing predicates, actions with parameters, preconditions, and effects.
action_modeler.goal: Produce a normalized and unambiguous action-and-predicate specification covering Paltry, Sip, Clip, Wretched, Memory, and Tightfisted, including parameter roles and effect polarities.

private_information: You convert textual initial conditions, object universes, and goals into grounded fact sets and scenario descriptors.
You do not emit PDDL; you produce structured instances for downstream conversion by the orchestrator.
state_analyst.goal: Assemble consistent grounded instances for the two scenarios; convert initial conditions and goals to sets of facts tied to the extracted specification.

private_information: You verify whether a given plan is consistent with a provided action model and an initial state; you explain any mismatches at the step and predicate level.
You do not emit PDDL; you produce diagnostics and, if coherent, a validated trace.
plan_checker.goal: Validate the provided plan for Scenario A against the extracted model and compiled initial state, reporting stepwise applicability, derived effects, and final goal satisfaction.

private_information: You synthesize the final PDDL domain and PDDL problem compatible with the Fast Downward solver based on upstream structured outputs.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate the model, instances, and diagnostics to generate a final PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for Scenario B, ensuring full Fast Downward compatibility and enclosing results in <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags.

public_information: paltry(x,y,z): preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, vase x y, next y z; effects: add next x z; delete vase x y.
sip(x,y,z): preconditions: hand x, cats y, texture z, next x z, next y z; effects: add vase x y; delete next x z.
clip(x,y,z): preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, next x z; effects: add vase x y; delete next x z.
wretched(x,y,z,w): preconditions: sneeze x, texture y, texture z, stupendous w, next x y, collect y w, collect z w; effects: add next x z; delete next x y.
memory(x,y,z): preconditions: cats x, spring y, spring z, next x y; effects: add next x z; delete next x y.
tightfisted(x,y,z): preconditions: hand x, sneeze y, texture z, next y z, vase x y; effects: add next x z; delete vase x y.

Scenario A initial conditions: cats object_0, collect object_10 object_2, collect object_5 object_1, collect object_6 object_1, collect object_7 object_1, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_2, hand object_11, hand object_12, hand object_13, next object_0 object_8, next object_11 object_10, next object_12 object_7, next object_13 object_7, next object_3 object_6, next object_4 object_9, sneeze object_3, sneeze object_4, spring object_5, spring object_8, stupendous object_1, stupendous object_2, texture object_10, texture object_5, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Scenario A goal: next object_11 object_5, next object_12 object_9, next object_13 object_10.

Scenario A plan: wretched object_3 object_6 object_7 object_1; clip object_13 object_3 object_7; clip object_12 object_3 object_7; wretched object_3 object_7 object_5 object_1; tightfisted object_13 object_3 object_5; tightfisted object_12 object_3 object_5; wretched object_4 object_9 object_10 object_2; clip object_11 object_4 object_10; wretched object_4 object_10 object_8 object_2; tightfisted object_11 object_4 object_8; sip object_11 object_0 object_8; memory object_0 object_8 object_5; sip object_13 object_0 object_5; sip object_12 object_0 object_5; paltry object_11 object_0 object_5; memory object_0 object_5 object_8; paltry object_13 object_0 object_8; clip object_13 object_4 object_8; paltry object_12 object_0 object_8; clip object_12 object_4 object_8; wretched object_4 object_8 object_10 object_2; tightfisted object_13 object_4 object_10; wretched object_4 object_10 object_9 object_2; tightfisted object_12 object_4 object_9.

Scenario B initial conditions: cats object_0, cats object_1, collect object_10 object_3, collect object_11 object_3, collect object_6 object_2, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_3, hand object_12, hand object_13, hand object_14, next object_0 object_9, next object_1 object_6, next object_12 object_11, next object_13 object_8, next object_14 object_8, next object_4 object_7, next object_5 object_10, sneeze object_4, sneeze object_5, spring object_6, spring object_9, stupendous object_2, stupendous object_3, texture object_10, texture object_11, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Scenario B goal: next object_12 object_6, next object_13 object_10, next object_14 object_11.

extract_spec.system_prompt: You transform natural-language action descriptions into a precise symbolic model without emitting PDDL. Extract and normalize: predicate names and arities, action names, parameter lists with roles, preconditions (positive only), effects (add and delete lists). Keep names exactly as given: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted; predicates: hand, cats, sneeze, spring, texture, stupendous, collect, vase, next.
extract_spec.prompt: Your name is action_modeler. Use the public information to produce a single, coherent action-and-predicate specification suitable for downstream PDDL synthesis. Include: 1) canonical predicate signatures, 2) action schemas with parameter order matching the human text, 3) for each action, the explicit preconditions and effects split into add and delete lists, 4) a complete set of symbols (objects may be referenced generically as object_i). Do not output PDDL; produce a clean structured summary. Context: {environment->public_information}. Your output handle is {model_spec}.

compile_instances.system_prompt: You assemble grounded instances from textual statements without emitting PDDL. Build two scenarios: A (with provided initial facts and goals and the human plan) and B (with provided initial facts and goals, no plan).
compile_instances.prompt: Your name is state_analyst. From the public information and the provided model specification, enumerate object symbols, ground the initial facts and goals for Scenario A and Scenario B, and package Scenario A's candidate plan as a sequence of grounded actions. Ensure symbol consistency with the model. Do not output PDDL. Inputs: {model_spec}. Your output handle is {instances}.

validate_plan.system_prompt: You verify plan applicability step by step using the structured model and grounded initial state for Scenario A. You do not emit PDDL.
validate_plan.prompt: Your name is plan_checker. Using the action model and Scenario A instance, simulate the given plan stepwise. For each step, report whether preconditions hold and list the state deltas (adds and deletes). At the end, report whether the Scenario A goals are satisfied and provide any counterexamples if not. Inputs: {model_spec}, {instances}. Your output handle is {plan_diagnostics}.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in synthesizing PDDL for Fast Downward. Produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem targeting Scenario B only. Use names exactly as in the model: actions paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted; predicates hand, cats, sneeze, spring, texture, stupendous, collect, vase, next. Ensure Fast Downward compatibility: classical STRIPS style, no conditional effects, no negative preconditions, no derived predicates, no functions. Include all objects needed by Scenario B. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem>.
pddl.prompt: Integrate the extracted model, the grounded instances, and any diagnostics. Then synthesize the final PDDL domain and the PDDL problem for Scenario B so it can be solved by Fast Downward. Requirements: 1) Domain: :strips; define all predicates and six actions exactly as specified with correct parameter orders and add/delete effects. 2) Problem: include all objects referenced in Scenario B, set the initial state per Scenario B, and set the goal to next object_12 object_6, next object_13 object_10, next object_14 object_11. 3) Use consistent symbol names and avoid any unsupported features. Output format: <domain>...</domain><problem>...</problem>. Inputs: {model_spec}, {instances}, {plan_diagnostics}. Your output handle is {pddl_fd}.
